transcripts.text: Bye.
How you doing, sir?
All right.  Scared me.
I'm Sergeant Zanoni with Security Forces.
Yes.
I work at the base.  Do you have any ID on you or anything?
Sure.
Do you mind if I see it?
Yeah, I do.  What have I done?  Have I done something wrong here?
So we're just wondering why you're videotaping installation or if there's, you know... What's your name, by the way?
My name's David.
Hey, David.
Just taking pictures of the visitor center, the gate, you know, the LED sign right there with that nice picture of the B-52 on it.  That's it.
Okay, so I know we have signs that say, like, restricted area and stuff and that you're not really supposed to be filming.
I don't see any signs that say there's no filming out here.
So traditionally, when you go up to like that morning sign over there, I believe it says no photography on it.  It doesn't.  Well, you want to go up and have a look at it?

No, I read it from here.  I can read it from here.  It says you can't come on the post without the permission of the commanding general.  And while you're on post, you're subject to searches.  That's it.  It doesn't say anything about photography.

So yeah, in the future then if you can just, so I'll just, we'll just consider this then in the future if you can not photograph around here and then our security.  So basically it looks like you're videotaping our security procedures and things and it just looks suspicious.  Does that make sense?  no it doesn't okay.  well and then you know.  so in this day and age with a lot of terrorism things going on it looks like you're out here doing surveillance on us.  so that's why we're out here and then you're not wanting to show us any identification.  so it just seems a little odd.  well and you know it doesn't really seem like it's on the level is if you're just out here wanting to go to the you know go to the museum or take pictures the museum's on the other side.  So there's no museum here, there's nothing really, I mean, obviously, your idea of something of photogenic value, something that's valuable to you photogenically, you may want to think this is a nice sign.  may not be what I would consider something of photogenic value.  However, if it's important to you and you want to take a picture of it, that's fine.  But on the other hand, if you want to just be a little tourist and just enjoy some good Air Force stuff and see some air power, the Air Power Museum is actually on the other side of the installation.  So it doesn't seem to me this would be the best spot for you to take those photos and to get the stuff you would like.  Does that make sense?
I'll address that.  Okay.  Number one, I don't think a terrorist would be standing here in a bright orange vest.
Oh, they do sometimes.
Out in plain view.  Really?
Mm-hmm.
Okay.

I mean, you don't have to be a terrorist per se.  You can just do... I mean, there's a lot of stuff.  There's surveillance, counter-surveillance.  There's a lot of things to do besides just staying, you know what I mean?

Mm-hmm.  Okay, well, I don't think that a person who was doing surveillance would be out here in broad daylight in plain view making no effort to conceal themselves or what they're doing and that they would have waited... for you guys to come out here and talk to him.  Okay.  I think that if you believe that's a terrorist, okay, I think you're in the wrong business, son.  Okay.  So now wait, number two, as for giving my name, I gave you my first name as a courtesy.  All right.  Just to kind of deescalate things here.  All right.  I didn't give you my entire name or my identification.  No, but I'm just saying, I won't give it to you because if I did, you're going to generate a report.  It's going to go over the fusion center.  They're going to forward it on to DHS.  I end up on terrorist watch list, okay, because I want to take pictures of a water tower and a golf course and an LED sign, you know.  I mean, come on.  It is out of control with that stuff.  The government is out of control with that stuff.  So that's why I wouldn't give you my personal information.  That's all.

Well, I understand that, but, you know, So you see how on my end that does look even more like it's not up to the car as well.  I didn't say I was generating for it.  I'm not pulling out a pen, paper, or anything else.  You know what I'm saying?  I'm not here with any paperwork.  I was just asking so I can see who you are.  You know what I mean?  I introduced myself.  I'm obviously in uniform wearing a name tape and everything else.  And if you want to take pictures of the water tower, I mean.
I already got them.
Right.  So you've obviously been out here for a while.
No, I just got here.

And there's plenty of, like you said, there's plenty of other places to go and plenty of other things to see.  And if you want to go to the museum, that's the museum score.  Go take pictures and see all that.
There are other things to be seen besides what's in the museum.
All right, sir.  So, David, you said?
David.
Okay.  All right.  So, what's your plans now, David?
I don't know yet.  I haven't really figured that out.
Okay.
It just looks suspicious when you're throwing gate operations.
I wasn't filming the gate operations.
Well, we don't know that.  If you're filming people coming into the base, they're filming our people working at the gate.

I mean, they're driving down a public road.  I mean, the government takes your pictures every day, all day.  I mean, there's probably 50 cameras within a mile of here.  You might be right, but you're the only one that's filming our gate procedures right now.  Y'all don't have a camera up there?  I think I see a camera up there.
You do, and it's pointing this way.
Okay.  So somebody somewhere is filming besides me.
Yeah, but they're not filming our gate operations.

It's us monitoring who comes into the base.  Okay, so you're comfortable with your people and the government monitoring what's going on here, but you're not comfortable with a citizen that comes out here to monitor it.
There's ways to do that.  You can go through PA, get permission to take pictures.

Why do I need permission to do something that's perfectly legal?  I'm not trying to be combative with you.  You seem like Webb.  You seem all right.  I know I'm coming across that way, and I'm sorry.  That's not how I mean to come across.  I'm just saying, you don't ask the government or the Air Force, well, you probably do, for permission to go drive down the road.  Why would you ask permission to take pictures if it's perfectly legal?  Now, I know I have to if I come on the base.  That's different.  But this is a public roadway.  It's a roadway that's paid for by my tax dollars and yours.  So you're just as, except for the fact that you're in the Air Force, you have just as much right to stand out here and take pictures as I do.

You're right, but like I said, there's procedures to how you do that.  Because we can't discern if you're a terrorist or not.  You could say, yeah, would a terrorist be wearing an orange vest?  I don't know.  They caught terrorists doing a lot more suspicious.
I know a little more about terrorism than you realize.
I'm just saying, I've been doing this for a while, and I've caught people that turned out to be a higher risk than you would think doing stuff that seemed perfectly normal.

Okay, and I understand that.  I've seen that myself.  But, I mean, come on.  And just waiting here to be discovered, it doesn't seem very logical.  You know, you have to consider the totality of the situation.  Okay, not just one little aspect, but the totality of the situation.  You're right.
But to me, you're filming the gate.

You didn't really give us a good explanation why you wouldn't pick the gate.  Okay, well, let me help you with that.  Let me help you with that, okay?  I'm an investigative journalist engaged in a constitutionally protected activity.  I'm an investigative journalist.  I'm engaged in a constitutionally protected activity.  That is all the explanation I need to give you.  And actually, I don't have to give you any explanation.  I mean, it's a public road.  I can do whatever I want so long as I'm not breaking law.  But I'm saying, as a courtesy, I've been forthcoming with information for you guys to kind of de-escalate situations.  So, that's what we're doing.  So, Mr.  What are you?  E5?  E6?  Yeah, I'm E5.  You guys got all the weird ranks.
No, we just happen to actually be here checking on some people.
No, I'm saying you guys got all these weird ranks.  It's Air Force.  I'm Army, so, you know, or was Army.
What'd you do in the Army?  Classified.  Okay.  GSG-14?
Classified, I can't tell you.
That's good.  What was your... How long ago were you in?
Long before you were born, I suspect.
That's what I'm figuring.
I'm quite a bit older than you, I believe.  Yeah.  What are you, about 30?
Oh, man, no.  You're just getting nice.
Don't stop me.  Don't say it.  How old are you?  40.  Are you kidding?  Yeah.  Wow.  That's nice.  Thanks.  I got you by about 16 years.
Not too bad, not too bad.
Yeah, so most of my service was in Europe.
Yeah?
Yeah.
So you retired or no?  No.  Where'd you go in Europe?
Germany.
Oh, okay.
I was fighting terrorists before you ever thought about getting in the Air Force.
Probably.
So what are we going to do here?
It's up to you, sir.  We're here because of you, right?  If you weren't here, we wouldn't be here.
Well, I'm hoping you just go back to work.
I'm about to, yeah.
Okay, good.
What are you going to go do then?
I'm going to take pictures.  That's what I do.
All right, sounds fair.
Are we calling the local PD?  I'm just saying, did you call the local PD?  Am I going to have to deal with them next?  Maybe.
You're not doing anything wrong.

You shouldn't have to.  You shouldn't have to worry about it, right?  I'm not worried about it.  I'm just asking.  I mean, I saw her making a phone call, so I'm just curious.  I'm not going to run.  I'm going to stand right here.  If they're coming, I'm not going to run from them.  I've done nothing wrong, so.  I hope you're not going to run.  I don't know.  There's nowhere to run to.
You need to do.  If you're going to go jog or whatever, I mean.

No, I'm going to go over here and take pictures of all the generals playing golf on the golf course.  Oh, it's not working.  Think that'll make them upset?  Generals really don't like to have their pictures taken.  I said, I'm going to go over here to the golf course and take pictures of the generals on the golf course.  I said, you think that'll make them upset?  I know generals don't usually like having their picture taken.
Yeah.  Yeah, I don't know.
Okay.  Well, I'm going to go back to what I was doing.  I appreciate your time coming out here to talk to me.  But we're good.  I'm not a terrorist.  I'm not here with any ill intent or ill purpose.
All right, David.
All right.  Have a safe day.  You too.
